title: Kerri-Anne Kennerley reveals how an MRI saved her life
text:
She was diagnosed with breast cancer seven years ago.

And television legend Kerri-Anne Kennerley has not forgotten the scary experience.

In an interview with The Daily Telegraph, the 66-year-old said that she hopes to save lives by sharing what she went through.

'It might have been a very different outcome': Kerri-Anne Kennerley (pictured) has revealed how an MRI saved her life after her shock breast cancer diagnosis

'A week before I had my [lumpectomy] surgery, my surgeon said that an MRI would give me a better plan for surgery and thank goodness I did because they found a second tumour which had not been picked up by the ultrasound and mammogram,' she explained.

The Studio 10 host recalled being left devastated after she was told the news.

'I thought, "What more? What else?" It wasn't fun,' she added.

Blessing: The Studio 10 host (pictured with her mother and late husband John) says if it weren't for an MRI scan, her cancer 'might have [had] a different outcome'

'Luckily they got it all out. If I didn't have an MRI, it might have been a very different outcome. I didn't have a mastectomy, I had a lumpectomy and I was very lucky it hadn't gone into the lymph nodes, which is the way breast cancer travels.'

The Morrison Government has committed $32.6million to subsidise MRI scans for breast cancer starting next month.

Earlier this year, Kerri-Anne lost her husband John Kennerley, who was previously left paralysed after a freak accident in 2016.

Painful: Earlier this year, Kerri-Anne (second from left, on Studio 10) lost her husband John Kennerley, who was previously left paralysed after a freak accident in 2016

Several weeks after John's death, Kerri-Anne broke down in tears on Studio 10 as she discussed life without her beloved husband-of-35-years.

'John and I had been a team for so many years,' she said. 'We were always together, we thought as two. And now there's only one. It hurts.

'My primary thought process is, "How would John react? What would John want me to do?"'

While she is now cancer free, Kerri-Anne continues to urge women - especially older women like herself - to get regular checks.
description: In an interview with The Daily Telegraph, the 66-year-old said she hopes that sharing what she went through can help save lives.
authors: David Wu For Daily Mail Australia
